The purpose of difficult elections and protests is to convince the rich to be less greedy.   When we have forced an audience by the strength of opposition, let us "weave" a relationship with respect for both sides.  Sanders is not oppositional, he is actually trying to help the rich to survive a difficult future. 

You all know what I mean.

There isn't any hope for collaboration when our leaders traffic in division, and their supporters' most satisfying goal is to upset or outright harm the opposition.

Apparently GOP officeholders are not only afraid of Trump's petty vengeance and losing their elections, but of being able to live in their own communities without being threatened or even attacked if they stand up to him.

Unfortunately, the U.S. is now past the point of rational deliberation and cooperation with those who hold different opinions.  Everyone is being driven by emotion, and a need to find someone else to blame for their own failures.

The country elected a president who has no compunction about unleashing the worst in us.  He is not a thoughtful, mature, well-intentioned individual.  He is barely civilized.  As a result, far too many of us now feel liberated to behave in a similarly uncivilized manner.

Human beings may be social and collaborative by nature, but with his cruel policies and pathological personality, Trump has set out to rob us of our humanity. His success in that regard is by far the most devastating damage he's done, and with the impending imprimatur of the Senate, will certainly continue to do.

I am a retired school counselor. Your statements are echoed in the IB program. I certainly won't argue that the goals you have stated are admirable. But they are also a utopia that will never exist in our lifetime. 

If we allow ourselves to think the American Spirit that built this great land will well up in the hearts and minds of the electorate and start chanting "we shall overcome", we will get conned by someone different than Donald Trump- but conned just the same. So those of us that will let's aspire to the principles you laid out. But let's keep the eyes in the back of our heads alert because there will still be individualists and populists who didn't get the memo that we aren't in a knife fight.

So this is just more "good people on both sides" from Mr. Brooks. No, there are not. Good people support human rights, not just white rights, not just straight rights, not just Christian rights. They do not force women and children to bear children they don't want. They do not refuse people worse off than them healthcare, food or shelter. They do not allow companies to recklessly pollute the only planet we have and must share. They don't demean the disabled. They don't worship liars. They respect the rule of law. They encourage and support all people to vote, not just those of the same party. They respect the truth even when it is uncomfortable. They understand the value of education and value of science. They understand that our global allies need to be treated with respect. There is, of course, more, but I think you get the idea. At this point, the only way to be a good Republican is to be an ex-Republican.

Brooks fails to understand the deep race, class, gender, religious, and cultural divide in America runs through our history, but the Republican Party and Trump have created a battle line between their rural white Christian base and the majority of urban liberals, Democrats, immigrants, minorities, feminists, the mainstream media, and LGBTQ. While his lecture against populism and individualism are based on his own professional, Manhattan media class bias, his tentative support of reparations for black people and Ro Khanna’s program for rural America show a connection to real people. Uniting America will take generations, but building an alliance on the class struggle of the multi-ethnic working people to tax wealth to make health care, basic income, green jobs, and college education basic human rights is possible now.

Trump is about cruelty to his opponents first, second, and always.

Bernie is about creating cooperative systems that benefit everyone, whether M4A, or free college, or any of his other ideas.

To David Brooks these are the same threat, but what is so threatening to a nice guy whose only real job has been to be wrong twice a week in print?  Does the specter of a laborer having access to the same medical care and education as the elites feel like it’s crushing the pundocracy?  Really?
Eloquent words, compassionate thoughts. But what our country has come to symbolize makes my heart weep for my children and grandchildren. And I bow my head.

The Future of American Politics will be driven by the same fundamental forces that will drive the Future of the Planet Earth. The climate crisis and the rapid destruction of the environment we depend on for life will lead us to cooperation or mutual destruction. 

Trump and the Republican Party use race and religion to undermine cooperative impulses and distract us by turning one tribe against another, promoting a war of all against all. 

And while we are distracted, they destroy protections for the water we drink and the air we breathe and promote the release of more CO2 and methane into the atmosphere in the name of more efficient markets. 

They are not only shredding relationships and community between people, they are shredding the relationship between humanity and the earth itself.
David Brooks, you are a humanist. Compassionate and expansive. I appreciate your diagnosis and your optimism. We are really in a tough bind now.

When you say self interest you are inferring that the interest is devoted to the accumulation of power and money. This reflects the core issue. It is less about self interest as it is about what that self is interested in. Look at how you define success, at who you admire. The base line is not about self interest or self sacrifice. It is about what you value.

David, I tend to agree with your premise when it comes to the American people in general. But we have been let down, no, betrayed, by institutions and leaders who put two things above the public good: money and power.  And when you add Trump's complete gaming of the system with no ability to check him for four years, it leads to despair.  The events of the last week in the Senate are in some ways worse than Trump because a whole body of our elected officials are trampling on the values that we hold dear:  that justice will prevail and no man is above the law.  If laws mean nothing and justice can't be found,  then all your social theories don't mean squat.

I agree that we should improve our discourse. How did the Fox News opinion lineup respond to your suggestions? Also, perhaps I missed your reference to the loss of the Fairness Doctrine. I'm sure you don't have kind words for the President  responsible for its demise.

Weaving is great when it works. But, too often abuse of power muffles good weaving. Take Wall Street and the Great Recession. A local political community on the fringe weaving its heart out with the best intentions, showing all the way up, learning from voices, valuing relationships, failing forward still gets crushed by the real estate bust. This is a problem, not an adventure. Now these people can weave in a homeless camp or a food shelter.   Their new goal: weaving for sanitation, warmth, clean water. 

Take the people of Flint, Michigan when the water was contaminated. All the best intentions weaving for the community dismantled by corrupt leaders cutting corners. 

Furthermore, if there are corrupt weavers, weaving in isolation, for their own profit, growth, dominance, what good is that? Facebook weavers enable Fake News and privacy issues. Gun Club weavers weave for loose gun control. Walmart higher-ups weaving to dismantle unions. Weaving can be all the things Brook's describes, but have unhealthy goals.

Maybe, more important than weaving are the systemic rules and laws put in our system which enable sustained access and fair outcomes. So healthy weaving can flourish across all economic platforms and root out corrupt weavers. The good Weavers can't weave without needed regulation and oversight on health care, education, fiance, banks, loans. Because corrupt weavers gonna weave too.

We are what we think we are.  If we convince ourselves that there is no such thing as society then we will act that way.  If we believe that we are nothing but a bunch of tribes vying for power and being the king of the anthill then that's how well act.  If we believe that through cooperation we can accomplish great things and that people working together in service of a common vision can create greater results then people isolated, alone and powerless then we will join together and create great things.  It's up to us to decide who we want to be.  For me, I believe in community, society, and the power of joining together to create a better future.  I'm not out to beat down my brother nor do I wish to live in a libertarian world where I remain powerless and alone seeking vainly only for my own self-interest.  I am not an Island entire unto myself.  I work to persuade others that they don't have to be a part of the stark world of individual powerlessness and selfishness or dog eat dog either.  We can choose to be better than that. It's all in our minds.  Make of the world what you want it to be.

Sadly , it’s becoming  clear that a willingness to seek collaborative social systems in this highly individualized society is a function of necessity and not simply a matter of choice and design . For many decades we have chosen the path of self -interest and tribal loyalty to the extent we are becoming a larger , more civil version of a Yugoslavia ; divided by religious , economic and cultural differences that serve only mistrust and enmity . What creates cooperation is a sense of a larger purpose and a redemptive narrative . Today , there are actually two crossroads that serve cooperation .First , to work tirelessly  to save our fragile    democracy from tyrants and those who abet this behavior by defeating them decisively at the ballot box .And  secondly    , to build without delay  a world that meets the challenge of climate change comprehensively  so our planet may survive and future generations flourish .As our parents and grandparents did in their generation , here lies the existential necessity for that sense of a weaving together that Mr . Brooks alludes to .

System complexity has surpassed processability by the democratic body politic.  Post post modernity means there is no center, left, or right, and consensus is impossible.  The founders could barely manage with 13 colonies and 4 million people.  It's way beyond time to accept this is the root problem and devolve authority to localities, where even there face to face compromise is just a possibility.  Hegemonic authority is the only realistic functioning system at massive scale (see China).  The sooner we accept this reality, the happier we will be.  Time to get over the nostalgia and move onto the new reality.

"The Future of American Politics" is an important topic.  But I don't agree with the Brooks slogan:

"We are an incredibly diverse society that got good at collaboration because we had to."

As a society we are avoiding the painful reality provided by global warming.  The planet will warm by 3.7 to 4.8 degrees C by the year 2100.  Prodigious efforts might get us a little below the lower estimate, but are progress so far has been laughably inadequate.

We need to

1.  Develop fission energy in the short term, fusion in the long term to supplement solar and wind.
2.  Develop worldwide policies that limit population growth.  It is immoral for families to have more than two children in an overpopulated world.

We need to rethink macroeconomics.  The models in the past have been based on the notion of perpetual growth.  Global warming makes that impossible going forward.

Neither party offers realistic policies.  Democrats don't seem to care that many of the poor are falling behind.  Thus people in the US DIE because they don't qualify for timely cancer screenings.

But our resources are limited.  Universal health care is impossible if it is coupled with open borders.

It is far better to help Guatemala control its birth rate than to pretend that we can provide homes to all the extra children it produces.  Virtually all of the Democratic candidates should be disqualified as innumerate except for those who can enunciate a plan to bring an end to illegal immigration.

David- I always enjoy reading your column, and your appearances on PBS.  But I think you missed your calling:  you're really a poet.  Your sensitivity and sensibilities are ever more evident with the passing of every month.  I sometimes wonder whether you chose to apply your talent to journalism because you're a realist who is financially responsible.  I look forward to your next column.  In a way it makes me sad that I do not share your optimism about the prospects of continued human rulership.  There is a better way, but it isn't in our genes to achieve it in a sustained and comprehensive way.  Millennia of spilled blood covering almost all the earth proves it.  But better days are coming.

If you ever write a book of verse, I will buy it.  Like a great piece of music, you just make me feel good.  Thank you.

Brooks' ideas are quite interesting and potentially very valuable to what most folks believe is American culture.  Unfortunately the idea of a shared concept does not exist in most Americans.  History gives us a general idea of how American class warfare is going to turn out in the Age of Controversy in which we are trying to survive.  
The last time America went through the American-me-First phase was in the 1920s under the leadership of the Republican Party, followed by the lovely days of the 1930s and then the not-so-lovely days of World War II.  History cycles because human nature never changes.  Brook's ideal world might come to exist in America someday but only after we have suffered through enough of the equivalents of the Great Depression and World War II.

I appreciate the exhaustion that David Brooks feels. Yet, I fear that there are many, many more miles left on America’s tribal warfare as far as American electoral politics is concerned. However, I think Brooks will reconsider his pessimism if he more closely examines the sociology of lived lives of Americans. Next time you’re in Southern California, you should visit places like San Gabriel Valley, the cities of Irvine, Oxnard, and Carson, the neighborhoods like Koreatown, South Los Angeles, and East Los Angeles, and Cal State University and University of California campuses. If he does, he’ll see that Americans of every color, class, and immigration status are pursuing their own and collective American Dream. The social reality is that people in their full diversity live and work, form friendship and families, study and find careers, run businesses and build lives, and, in doing so, they weave their lives and fates together. This is not true just in the coastal cities—Houston and Dallas are now immigrant gateway cities, Oklahoma has the fastest growing interracial marriage rate in the country, and Kansas will cheer on their bi-racial quarterback this Super Bowl Sunday. If Brooks—as well as the rest of us—can pop the political bubble and the media echo chamber, we would see not only the promise of America but the promise being brought to life everyday in every corner of America not through grand gestures but in everyday actions.

David presents a beautiful positive vision of national community, a town hall dance for the nation. I like it, a lot, but then I remember Trump, the great divider and chief. And I remember how I have tried to replicate family reunions for my extended family, like we used to, but it no longer works because my relatives inevitably talk about their clan allegiance instead of family doings. Then a verbal skirmish breaks out, and some folks drive away in a cloud of dust. I just don't know how to spin gold out of straw.

I am going to be blunt; the conventional constraints that were the glue holding society together have dissolved. I have witnessed county government completely falling apart caused by people who have absolutely no conscience or selflessness. Scott Walker, a cynical, self absorbed politician, presaged Trumpism by six years in Wisconsin. If you travel across our country, you will see a nation that is riddled with homelessness, drug addiction, hopelessness, and dismal, dilapidated sprawl. Over 20 veterans commit suicide every day along with the increasing suicide rate among all Americans. Our system held together all these years because it was largely inhabited by people of good will and good conscience. That simply doesn't exist anymore. The reality is that the unscrupulous, unconstrained, have unlimited power under our system. If there are truly people of good will left, they are few and far between in politics. I am afraid there is no going back, and it can never be the way it was. Anyone with optimism is not living in the real world.

As is so often the case, David Brooks conservatism, while identifying some important principles (like the need for more community and cooperation), places it in a false equivalency.  The difference between the left and the right, excepting some individuals, is that the left wants more egalitarianism while the right tries to justify privilege, extreme economic inequality, and includes those that denigrate other groups such as people of color, non-Christians, immigrants and so on.

While we should welcome those on the right to jettison elitist and racist views that separate us, we loose the very principles that Brooks lauds if we compromise with the right broadly. Remember, it was Reagan and Thatcher, those scions of current republicans, that were some of the main popularizes of "the individual is everything" and Milton Friedman the godfather of the economics of greed. 

It is unfortunate that we are at a point where we must fight for community and egalitarianism, contrary to Brook's vision, but those of us on the left did not ask for this!

It never ceases to amaze me that so many talking heads will mention “human nature” and then go on to perform the required argument that both sides, liberal and conservative, are actually equally to blame in the “Tribal” war. 
   Are humans tribal by nature? Yes, of course because we evolved that way as stated here, but the crucial point is that tribes are relatively small by definition but when the tribes evolve and grow into nation states then that’s where true. cooperation is required and then you have the real conflict between liberals who advocate inclusiveness and tolerance and conservatives who, by definition, want slow to no change and for “tradition” to rule.  This is the crux. Tradition may be quaint in letting aunt Sally to always put the star on the Christmas tree but not when wanting the privileged ruling class to maintain their privilege.  Tradition is just a warm fuzzy and rarely beneficial to a big society and it has always been the conservatives who use it to manipulate the populous.   Tolerance and inclusiveness just isn’t their thing.  Both sides are not equally the problem.  A false equivalency and a misuse of the word, “Tribalism”.   Humanity passed that a long time ago.  We just kept the emotions of it.  Emotionally, we are definitely tribal and think tradition is a good thing when it’s definitely not.
The tribalisms of religion is at the heart of it no matter how much we want to deny it.  What could possibly be more tribal than religion? There’s others.

People compromise and cooperate when they are wanting something that cannot be achieved any other way.  When one person or group of people has what they want and can keep it without losing anything they truly care about there is no need to be concerned about the needs of others.  Brooks fails to realize this very basic fact and though there are serious problems with this country there are those among us who have exactly what they want and no compulsion or desire to change.  You can label it evil but honestly it is just human nature.

We as a country can only move forward when we are on more equal footing but the reality is that the wealthy control us.  They have bought our government, they have bought our legal system, they have bought our sources of information, and they have manipulated vast sections of this country to see them as the answer instead of the problem.

Weaving is fine and all but it has no chance in the environment that exists currently.  The only way for it to be anything but a dream is to recognize what stands in its way which is the Conservative movement.  Here in the midst of an impeachment trial where one party won't allow a single witness with pertinent information to be heard, how can you not see the problem and name it for what it is?  A single group holds enough power to undermine our system of justice and Brooks again wants to say it is both sides.  Brooks is not helping anyone or anything but his idea of himself with this opinion.

Oh my god, I am starting to agree with David Brooks more often than not. Is this what getting older means?

In all seriously, I am deeply disturbed by the divisiveness I'm hearing from BOTH sides of the political spectrum. Yes, it's true that in many ways, Republicans "started it." Yes, the scorched-earth rhetoric of Trumpism has many led many otherwise sensible people to see 40% of their countrymen as an enemy to be destroyed. And yes, that's how the Trump cult sees us "coastal elites" who aren't on board with the anti-science, anti-immigrant, "post-truth" agenda of this administration.

But what I'm really longing for is a candidate who could bring people together. Beyond all of the hateful rhetoric and the mayhem of social media, there ARE things that the vast majority of Americans agree on: universal background checks for gun owners, the right to health care, infrastructure spending, and more. But talking about those things just doesn't play in the supercharged, hyper partisan atmosphere we live in now.

This is why I think Andrew Yang would be the best person to heal America and bring prosperity to the rest of the country. At a basic level, he respects everyone's humanity. 

He doesn't insult Trump voters, or write them off as other candidates often do; he believes that the hollowing of the middle class, and the crushing of the poor in today's economy has forced people to try anyone they think will help them. The 4 million manufacturing jobs lost in the last couple decades weren't actually going to come back under Trump, but he was at least talking about the issue. What was Hillary's response? America is already great. Thats not going to win any votes from people whose entire livelihood has been automated away. 

Yang is willing to engage figures like Ben Shapiro and Tucker Carlson without vitriol, and believes it is a mistake for Democrats to avoid going on Fox News. After all, he said "How can you bring a country together if you aren't even interested in talking to 40% of the population.

While I generally like Yang's policies a lot, it is really his approach that I admire above all. I would encourage anyone curious about Yang to watch an interview with him on Youtube. I know his unorthodoxy is off-putting when you hear about him, but I think listening to him speak for himself will greatly shift your perception.

Not Left. Not Right. Forward.

We are what we are because of the help and kindness of people all around us in spite of our individual shortcomings. I’m surprised that people don’t see it that way. Yes there are charlatans and people who try to put us down, but by and large we live and survive due to the generosity of the world at large.

Yes, Republicans and Democrats are so polarized that they consider how common problems are addressed help or harm their ability to control the government and to determine national policies. 

Trump has always defied laws which he sees to be obstacles whenever can get away with it. He will only respect boundaries that firmly restrict him. By not holding Trump accountable he will do worse. By refusing to stop him, Republicans are undoing our body politic and leaving a set of circumstances where our laws are ineffective by allowing Trump to defy them with impunity.

Mr. Brooks paints a pretty picture, but it is unrealistic.  Yes, a person's primary interest is usually self interest. And, once upon a time, maybe, people (e.g.  elected officials) could moderate their self interest for the greater good.  This required vision and moral principles that were adhered to.  Today, we are surrounded by so many people who have abandoned moral principles, let alone any sense of cooperation, that it will take a significant outside threat to bring people together ... at least for a little while.

The Democratic Party has these things, although imperfectly, and tries to do them.  The Republican Party does not have or want these things, and tries to block the Democrats at every turn.  

The Democratic Party is dishonest in the way politicians are dishonest.  Republicans have brought political dishonesty to new levels, taking over and perfecting the political dishonesty the formerly Democratic South showed in race relations.  (The Democratic South used to defend segregation, disenfranchisement, and the inability to catch or punish lynchers.)    

Nancy Pelosi is a weaver of the various strands in the Democratic Party.  Mitch McConnell, Newt Gingrich, and other recent Republican leaders have been bullies rather than weavers; dissent is punished.  

The radical critique of neoliberalism is not entirely correct rather than not entirely wrong.  Calling it the latter is an example of the sort of dishonesty that, when carried to extremes as it is today, makes learning about anything except dishonesty and propaganda impossible.  

To get organizations in America to live by these values, we must first name those that dont and then look for ways to get them to change their ways.  Our present system of laws doesnt work very well; for the rich our system has the deterrent power of referees in professional wrestling, while the poor get plea-bargained whether they are innocent or guilty.

Brooks’ argument is built on a very false equivalency between the right and the left. The left is not the faction that just upheld the right of a president to abuse his power without limit and without consequences. This nation drove into its current ditch by following a road paved with such false equivalences. One of the big turning points in this drive to dictatorship was the coverage of Hillary Clinton’s alt right speech. Both on air and on line CNN dismissed her speech as a partisan maneuver. An August 25, 2016 article on CNN’s website, for instance, declared that Clinton’s comments “mark a dramatic escalation in the war of words between Clinton and Trump.” CNN did not have the courage to admit that Clinton’s assertion that “Trump has built his campaign on prejudice and paranoia.” Brooks is following in that grand CNN tradition.
Great observations.  I'd like to understand how "we" got so far away from civil dialogue and mutual respect.

Good luck!  

Ironically, where collaboration is most likely to work is two places: Sports teams and corporations.  In some ways, our government is designed to move slow.  But what we’re seeing today is a big fat waste of time and money.  And that’s on both parties.

I appreciate your thought. 

Perhaps the first step in the process is honesty. For collaborative healing to begin we must first be honest with ourselves. Bringing personal integrity back into the collaborative discourse is essential. Otherwise, we will continue projecting our self hatred on each other.

Once we can recognize and accept our own fear and insecurity, we can then make positive contribution to a collaborative effort. 

The thought of actually moving forward in a positive collaborative way is so refreshing. Leaving far behind the oppression and stagnation we have created through partisan divide.

Thank you.

For me the answer is for Democrats is to win big this fall.  I hope Biden is the nominee and that he names a black woman, Stacy Abrams perhaps, to be his running mate.  I also think he should renounce a second term and thus pledge the Democratic ticket to be a restoration of normalcy and decency.

I think announcing at the convention a one term-presidency and several cabinet assignments  to prominent Democrats  who would campaign to elect a "team" to govern the nation would help to bring about the landslide victory needed.   A big win renounces Trump and trumpism loudly at the polls where it matters most.   Impeached by the people thirsting for justice.

There is need for at least two parties, but all parties should need to play by fair rules that result in fair and balanced electoral districts, and fair campaign funding that lets everyone have a chance to fairly influence who gets elected.

One party can dominate and govern, and in office can show the people who they are.  When the people don't believe the government, they can chose other representatives.  One party may dominate, but the other out-of-power parties need to reinvent who they are and come up with policies people want in order to return to power.  That's the challenge the GOP faces this fall.

There must be choices, and there must be fair rules.  When we can see a more moderated political discourse, moderate republicans and conservative democrats, we will know we have made progress healing our democracy.

I fear the last few Republicans who might have had the courage to work across the aisle retired for fear of working across the aisle. 

In two years, amendments to the Constitution will be made in a week, and the first amendment will be to throw out the two ways to amend the Constitution.

We are an authoritarian regime now, it's just going to take until December of 2020 for it to really crank up.

Dear Mr. Brooks, what you described in your column Is the way I live my life. You are correct, collaboration with other well meaning, committed individuals is the the road to prosperity. I hear you, then I look, and listen to the mean-spirited gang of conservative thugs running the impeachment trial in the senate, and I fear for my country. Now is the time, there may not be another opportunity, to find the people that share your values, then fight the powers that be! Vote blue, no matter who!

........I so enjoy when Mr. Brooks writes in this vein, down this alley.

We have plenty of crisis points.  We have far fewer concepts and paths to create a future where we live in peace, together.

This editorial is a blueprint, one way of building a shared future.

My wish;  that Mr. Brooks would branch out, and write in detail, and with some anguish, about the state of our global environment.  Because, in the end, isn't living on a healthy beautiful planet the whole point of also working together and getting along?

Right now I am so depressed over the lack of integrity and ethical cooperation on the part of Republicans in the US Senate, that it's hard to envision collaboration in government. We once had it. Will we ever have it again.  I want to be optimistic.  Maybe I will be in the future but at this moment in time, I am not.

It is funny how the author is calling for open-mindness, and yet sticks to old cliche 'capitalism is great'. Of course, it is nice to cooperate, but in order to cooperate there should be unifying goals. It is difficult to find such goals in absence of external threat, if your society divided by wealth: the wealthy  concern that their pearls are too small, and the poor concern that their bread is bitter. What about these two group will cooperate? Work on increasing size of pearl, or on feeding the poor? Sure, you can try to do both, but that would be not cooperation, it will be pursuing separate goals of two separate a groups that investing their effort in different goals.

Self interest well displayed as the Republican Senators voted to cover up the cover up. Self interest over constituent interest. A long way from teamwork Mr. Brooks. 
They have essentially agreed that the President is above the law and the constitution is dead. If a Dem gets elected feel free to abuse at will. What next?

"Human beings didn’t evolve into the world’s dominant species because we are more autonomous. We didn’t do it because we’re more vicious in tooth and claw. We thrived as a species because we are better at cooperation."

Human thriving has been a disaster for other species. Our ability to cooperate makes us more efficient at exploiting (and destroying) the rest of the natural world. Resolving our internal conflicts and speeding progress may merely lead us faster along an already risky path. Be careful what you wish for.

In James A. Robinson's book, "Why Nations Fail," he theorizes the difference between nations that have 'inclusive' vs an 'extractive' institutions.  The former having values centered around cooperation in the achievement of goals benefiting many and not the few.  In the latter type of institution, the emphasis is placed on individual achievements at the expense of the community.  For example, in third world countries, we often see wholesale corruption benefiting government officials and those with ties to those officials.  We see an abusive of power benefiting the few and not the citizenry.  Corrupt leaders out to extract whatever increases their wealth at the expense of the welfare of the nation.

This is a beautiful piece that puts a bit of sweetness into one of the most frightfully depressing days in the history of our democratic republic. 

Thank you!

Two of your key recommendations: "Be fully present, honest and vulnerable..." and "Learn from all voices" can be a brave path chosen by individuals.

However, without the repeal of Citizens United, and without an effective antibody to the increasing dominance of the a-factual, effective propaganda of Fox News, talk radio and social media, it is not entirely possible to "learn from all voices":

•	First, one can only hear all voices, if the most rich and powerful voices cannot effectively drown out many of the poorest and least powerful voices.

•	Second, your plea, Mr. Brooks, implies an authenticity of "voice" - the deepest yearnings of one person connecting with the deepest yearnings of another. If there are no shared facts, then one or more of the parties are effectively brainwashed, and there can be no true connection.

We need to have the smarts and the courage to deal with the evil of propaganda that is superpowered by money, technology and the dark artists that are willing to manipulate people rather than win their votes the old fashioned way.

Let’s take what Brooks has written and extend it to its logical conclusion.  
When you live outside the US and have been in different counties, you get exposed to the idea of the ‘Individual’ vs. ‘The Group’.   If ‘Individualism’ is one bookend and ‘The Group’ is the other, then you find that you can rank countries as to where they are on that continuum between those extremes.   What you find is that the US is far to the individualistic end of the spectrum with Europe in the middle and Asia on the other end.  

In fact, you can’t truly understand the rest of the world until you understand this concept.  For example, China will never give up ‘State Capitalism’ because it is the gold star in ‘Group’ culture.  Believing that you can change that behavior is utterly laughable since it is an inherent part of their culture.

At one point in time, the US leapfrogged the world with individualism.  However, we have long hit the point of diminishing returns.  In fact, our culture needs to move in the other direction both socially and economically.  
From this point forward, we need to add elements of ‘The Team’ to our culture.  The NFL is not just a collection of individuals, it’s also requires teamwork if you have any hope of winning.  If we don’t add elements of teamwork to our culture, we will just fade away.

Generalities and Hallmark sentiments do not a political philosophy make.
